claim: If class sizes at the Los Angeles school with the most SAT test takers scoring at least 1500 had been capped at 15 students, the average SAT writing score there would have exceeded 500.
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim. It hypothesizes about what would have happened ('If class sizes had been capped at 15 students... the average SAT writing score would have exceeded 500'). Databases record actual data, not outcomes of hypothetical scenarios. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from a database and must be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
This claim contains counterfactual language: "If class sizes... had been capped at 15 students, the average SAT writing score there would have exceeded 500." This is a hypothetical "what if" scenario describing what would have happened under different conditions.

According to my workflow rules, counterfactual claims — those describing hypothetical scenarios — should ALWAYS be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO, because databases record what actually happened, not what would have happened under imagined changes.
